document.text: Youth Saves Up Pennies To Pay for His Wedding RALEIGH, N. C.Four years ago, Van H. Womble of New Hillthen only 19 years oldbegan saving his pennies to get married. He walked into the office of Regis trar of Deeds Hunter Ellington the other day and handed over 500 pen nies for a license to wed Jessie Mae White, 20, of Graham. Womble paid the officiating min ister with 10 in pennies.

document.text: Your residents may read about your state and local government operation by read ing the informative booklet Your Virginia State Govern ment. Published by the Virginia League of Women Voters, this- Bicentennial édition has chap ters on the state constitution, the citizens role in state government, courthouse and city hall and Virginias role in the federal union just to name a few. Described as a concise, easily understood description of Virginias government and how it works, it is available at 1.50 per copy or 1.25 per copy in lots of 50 from 1870 Hunter Mill Road, Vienna, Va. 22180. Checks should be made payable to the League of Women Voters of Virginia.

document.text: Your lofty Miss Carrington cut mo dead today, uncle, reported Robert, later in the same week. Oh, you must be mistaken, remon strated Mr. Laldlaw.  .Not at all, it was palpable and meant. You see, I had my working clothes on and the grime of honest labor shocked her sensitive spirit. Hm! muttered the old man thoughtfully, and then he went to his lawyer. See here, Hunter, he began lo the attorney. Im doing that boy a wrong. in what way? was the pertinent query. Mr. Laidlaw narrated his story of the disadvantages of menial employment in the eyes of the higher sociul set. He further deplored the arduous labor which was hardening the hands of his protege, the slow promise of final ad vancement. The lawyer chuckled. Tired of the program, eh, already that I laid out to make a real man of your nephew? he challenged. What you want to dorear him in the lap of luxury and spoil him? Welleryou see No, you see! Laidlaw, Interrupted the lawyor briskly, Tve been studying I young Robert and Im glad to observe his sense, courage and fidelity to an ideal. Hell work out right and make you proud of him if you leave him alone. Yes, but he may make friends among the well, the lowlythat may be a detriment to him. What! rallied the lawyer, after our proud-tempered Miss Carring- on? Rut suppose he should fall in love with some poor girl? Suppose he did? Do you want to spoil his happiness? No, you go right ahead on the course we have marked out. Robert is no fortune hunter or he wouldnt havo chosen you instead of your brother, he would never have isked catching an heiress by under taking menial employment. Hes gen uine, concluded the attorney. True blue ail through and ail of the time, liell land right. Mark my words. There came a test. An unexpected event transpired. James Laidlaw died and in a will he had planned to change when his nephew refused to live with him, but which he had neglected to do, his sole heir was Robert. Now hell go off on his own hook, 1 suppose, grumbled Mr. Laidlaw to his lawyer no further use for me. I Wait and see, advised the law yer. It was a week later when Robert came into the library and addressed his relative. Uncle Henry, he said bluntly, I want you to accept half of the fortune Uncle James left me. You were closer to him than 1 am, and should by right inherit it. You are not rich Who told you that? exploded the old man. If Ive hidden my wealth from you, it was for a purpose. All the same, he said in a lower tone, Im glad to see that you have a loyal, grateful heart. Its a division, no matter what you say, declared Robert, you see, If we could all live together Wearent we? What you up to now? demanded the old man suspi ciously. Whyyou see, theres a Nellie. And who is she? Let me bring her around and see, suggested Robert, which he did. She was not of the horn princess typeonly a modest, retiring girlbut inside of five minutes she had wound herself about the old mans ingenuous heart just as she had done with Robert Laidlaw.

document.text: YOUNG BOXING HOPEFULS shown above from left are Cecil Hunter, 15, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hunter, Randy St. John, 13, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert St. John, Jeff Chauncey, 10, son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle Chauncey, Gary Ferguson, 11, son of Mrs. Joyce Ferguson, and Jimmy Martin, 15, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Martin. According to Marc Stone, instructor, these young men are really working hard to learn the fundamentals of boxing. The Appomattox Boxing Club, sponsored by the Jaycees, is in its first year and boasts an enrollment of 42. Jaycee President Raymond Mullins has issued a plea for more coaches and trainers and requests that anyone having any experience in boxing and who is willing to donate several hours a Week, contact him or come by the Appomattox Depot on Monday or Wednesday night or Saturday morning. Exercise bicycles are badly needed for training purposes and the loan or donation of one or more will be appreciated. A regulation size ring is under construction and the fighters will soon he practicing what they have been taught. During the next several months there will be tournaments in Appomattox, Charlotte and Richmond with the State Tournament scheduled j in Norfolkon April 21.

document.text: Yes, tor some people ln this world there seems no let-up. They are pursued from youth to manhood, and from manhoodto old age. Very distinguished are Lord Staf fords hoUnus, the Earl ot Yarboroughs honnds, and Qaeen Victoria pays eight thousand live hundred dollars per year to her Master Ot Backhonnds. But all of them put together do not equal in number or speed, or power to hunt down, the great kennel ot hounds ot which Sin and Trouble are owner and master. Bnt what Is a relief forall this pursuit ot trouble, and annoyance, and pain, and be reavement? My text gives It to you In a word of three letters, bat each letter is a harlot if you would triumph, or a tbron If yon want to be orownod, or a lake It yon would slake yonr thirstyes, a chain ot three lakesO-O-D, tbe One for whom David longed, and the One whom David found. You might ns well meet a stag whleb, after Its sixth mile of running at the top most speed through thicket and. gorge, and with the brehth Of the dogs on Its heels,has come in fnll sight ot Serooh Lake, and try to ctjbl Its projeetlng and blistered tongue with a drop of dew from a blado ot gloss,ns to at tempt to satisfy an Immortal soul,when fly ing from trouble and sin, with anything less deep, and high, and broad, and immense, and Infinite, and eternal tiian God. Hto comfort, wby it embosoms all distress. Hls arm, it wrenches off aU bondage. Hls hand, It wipes away all tears. His Obrlstly atone ment, It makes us all right with the past, and all right with the future all right with God, all right with man, and all right for ever. Lamartine tells us tbat King Nimrod said to hls three sons, Hero aro three yokes, and one is ot clay, another of amber, and another ot gold. Choose now which yon will have. The eldest son, having first ohoice, chose the vase of gold, on whloh was written the word Empire, and when opened it was found to contain human blood. The second son, making tho next, choice, ohose the vase ot aml0r.Jns with the 1 nuTwM f openod I  jUma the ashes of these who were Called great. The third son took tho of clay, and, oponing It, found it _ ptv bat on the bottom of it was in- scrlral the name ot God. King Nimrod asked bis oourtlers whloh vase they thought weghed the most. The avaricious men ot hiseourt said the vase of gold. The poets said the one of amber. But tho wisest men said the empty vase, because ono letter ot the name of God outwoighed a universe. For Him I thirst for Hte gram I beg on Hls promise I build my all. Without Him I cannot be happy. I have tried the world, and it does well enough as far it goes, but It Is too uncertain a world, too evanescent a world. I am not a prejudiced witness. I have nothing against this world. I have been one of the most fortunate, or to use a more Christian word, one of the most blessed of menblessed in my parents, blessed ln the place of my nativity, blessed In my health, blessed ln my field of work, blessed in my natural temperament, blessed In my family, blessed in my opportunities, blessed in a comfortable livelihood, blessed In the ho,e that my soul will go to Heaven through the pardoning mercy ot God, and niy body, unless it be lost at sea or cre mated in some conflagration, will He down ln the gardens of Groenwood among my kindred and friends, some already gone and others to come after me. Life to many has been n disappointment, bnt to me It bas been a pleasant surprise, and yet I de clare that It I did not feel tbat God was now my Friend and ever-present help, I should be wretched and t error at icken. But I want more of Him. I have thought over this text aud preached this sermon to myself until with all the arouse.l energies of my body, mind and soul, I can ory out, As tbe liart panteth after the water brooks, so panteth my soul after Theo, O God. Ob, when some of yon get there it will be like what a hunter tells of when push ing his eanoe far up North ln the winter and amid the Ice-floes, and a hundred miles, as he thought, from any other human be ings! He was startled ono day as he heard astepplng on the ice, and he cocked his rifle ready to meet unythlng that came near. He found a man, barefooted and In sane from long exposure, approaching him. Taking him into bis canoe and kindling fires to warm him, he restored him and found out where be had lived, and took him to hls home, and found all the village ln great excitement. A hundred men were searching for the lost man, and bis family and friends rushed out to meet him and, as had been agreed at hls first appearance, bells were rung, and guns were fired, and banquets spread, and the rescuer loaded with presents. Well, when some ot yon step oat of this wilderness, where yon have been chilled and torn ag sometimes lost amid the Iceberg warm greetings of all tbe villages  th e glorified, and your friends rush o u t to give you weleomlng kiss, the news that th e r e to another soul forever saved will c all th e caterers ot Heaven to spread tho banquet and the bell-men to lay hold of the ro p e in the tower, and while tbe ehallees eliek at the feast, and the bells clang from the tur rets, it will be a scene so uplifting I p ra y God I may be there to take part in th e celestial merriment. Until tbe d a y break and the shadows flee away, be th o u like a roe or a young hart upon the mouse tains of Bether.

document.text: wv.uuMXHivn  JLUiVIIVI IUU dered valuable service to the farmers by posting and patrolling privately owned game sanctuaries, totaling nearly 200,000 acres in raising ana releasing, in the rural sections, nearly 6.000 bobwhite quail, and in protect ing during the closed season game birds and animals which are a valu able asaet on any farm, and which without such protection would shortly become exterminated. The Commission has under con sideration the acquisition of the hunt ing and fishing rights in the foreat lands owned by the United States Gov ernment in the State, aggregating 600.000 acres, to be re-stocked and opened as public hunting and fishing grounds, and of acquiring, by lease or purchase for similar purposes, areas in other sections of the State where there are no Federally owned forest lands, and likewise of establishing certain sanctuaries or game refuges where game birds and animals can be raised in the native State, to be trap ped and distributed to other sections where most needed. The Commission is also considering the establishment of two fish hatcheries for the re-stoek- ing of the bass and trout streams and ponds in the State. The survey of the work of the Com mission for the past fiscal year indi cates the importance of its activities and the efficiency with which the task is being handled. Great possibilities lie in store for it in restoring Virginia to its pristine claim of being a hun ters paradise, and its work entitles it to the hearty support and co-operation of the farmers and conservationists of the Commonwealth. During the course of the day the ad- ! visory committees appointed by the! Commission had conferences and made recommendations. The recom- ! mandations of two of the committees  follow Recommendations of Advisory Com mittee on Upland Game 1. We are firmly of the opinion that the Commission of Gpma and Inland Fisheries should be given full regu- ! latory powers as are new vested in the  boards of supervisor. W think that the Commission of Game and Inland Fisheries is in a better position to know about bag limits, seasons, etc., in all sections of the State. 2. General game and fish laws should be codified and simplified.  We are of the opinion that the State Game Farm should continue to rail quail, and recommend that in the distribution of these quail to the dif ferent sanctuaries that particular at tention should be given to the sane tuarics on which birds will be re leased, ascertaining if the parties who propose to provide these sanctuaries are properly interested in game con servation and whether the place is a proper one on which to put game. We recommend that tha present method of distributing quail from the farm be carefully Investigated, as we ate of the opinion that If birds are held longer and not released so young bet ter results will be obtained. 4. We are inclined to recommend that a license be put on cats. The committee is of the opinion that hunt ing eats are more destructive to up land game than any other varmint. 5. The committee does nbt think there should be any change, in the present license law. We are firmly of the opinion that the fee of three dollars Is low enough snd should not be changed. 6. This committee also recommends that a law be passed prohibiting the use of any gun fpr upland game that shoots over twice. 7. We recommend that some law be passed that all dogs be tied up in reeding season, or if allowed to run at large to be compelled to wear a muzzle. 8. We recommend that every hunter e required to dieuplay his licenae. -Recommendations tor Advisory Com mittee oq Fur Bearing Animals 1. No hunting of rabbits when snow is on the ground. 2. Squirrel season to open and dose with the quail season. 3. Close season on bears. 4. Trappers to pay 10.00 licenae and 16.00 for non-reaidenta. Trappers to report to Commission of Game and ïn- and Fisheries number of traps and ilo all animals and varmints So raught. Trappers must be compelled -o visjt traps at least once a day. 5. Fur industry to Virginia is val- lable and should be protected and its peration should come under a State .W. 6. A law prohibiting dropping cate ,n highways. 7. Regulation of laws be left in ands of Commission of Game and In- and Fisheries. 8. Foxhuntera to pay hunting iccnse. Resolutions Passed The following resolutions were pass- 1 by the gathering 1. It is the sense of this body, com posed of these advisory committees, hat the Commission of Game and In- and Fisheries should have given it by he Legislature regulatory powers ow exercised by the Boards of Super io rs . 2. It is the sense of this body tist he reports submitted, by the advisory orqtnittees he turned over to the Commission for deliberation and ccc mmendation and their report be urned over ,to the Legislature. document.text: Working Golls. Some 50 girl students of Hunter college, a city institution, have earned about 25,000 in less than five months, and one of the girls gets 7 a week for taking a dog for a dally walk. An other earns considerably more giving bridge lessons, and most of the stu dents work in department stores. the cathedral. Over the levee below poised the masts of ships from the old country. Through the high and troubled times of history the old market passed with few-changes. Andrew Jackson paused there, Lafayette drank there the black french drip coffee that finds partisans throughout the world. There Thack eray took notes, and Jenny Lind won- deringly sniffed the mingled odors. Under four Hags it dispensed food. French soldiers, OReillys Spaniards, the patriots whom they shot, Muff Tennessee riflemen came with- each turned page of history. Ragged Con federates reluctantly left the stall and triumphant blue-clad Invaders ex perimented with the food that sup planted the army rations they bad known.  Roosevelt Loved It Presidents of a later day frequented It. Roosevelt loved. It, and Taft paid tribute by eating a giant tureen of river shrimp bought them.. Harding, old residents say, enjoyed its delica cies when a senator. Through It all, the old market went serenely about the business of feeding Its people. When the French quarter became the residence of the Immigrant late In the Inst century, It fed-the Im migrant along with the visiting gran dee. When living In the quarter be came the fad of the artist, and society came to drink midnight coffee there, the market served all impartially. The Louisiana Historical society plans to commemlrate fittingly thess 200 years of service and history. The anniversary celebration will come Just In time. The old market Is to be destroyed. Where the old stalls stand a sanitary modern market will be erected as soon as the necessary financing and legislation la accomplished. But, say ita devotees, It will still be the-old French market

document.text: With TWENTY-THREE volunteer clerks assisting through long hours out of pure patriotism, and with two paid clerks putting in many hours of free overtime, the Appo mattox County War Price and Ra tion Board is waging an uphill bat tle to administer the rapidly ex panding activities of the Office ol Price Administration. The Ration Board itself has been in s ssion every day this week from 1 to 6 P. M. and will continue its five-hour daily meetings through July 22, at least, in an effort to act on truck and non-highway appli cations for gasoline under the new rigid gas rationing which goes into effect July 22. The board members, who are giving their services with out pay, urge that wherever at all possible, passenger cars owners give their  A books a thorough trial before they appeal for a supple mental ration. Bolunteer clerks who are helping applicants fill out the complicated blanks for service rations of gas, are Mrs. Joel W. Flood, chairman, Mrs. Gordon 9pencer, Mrs. J, T. Hunter, Mrs. J. C. Caldwell, Mrs. Caroline B. Cates, Mrs. J. T. Hunt er, Misses Myrtle Smith, Virginia Christian and Mildred McDearmon, and W. E. Hancock and S. A. Law- son.

document.text: With the opening of the general hunting season in Virginia on Nov. 18, many hunters will come in con tact wilbh the wild rabbit, principal source of the infectious disease, tularemia. Dr. Mack I. Shanholbz, State Health Commissioner, notes that the months of November, December and February generally show the largest incidence of reported cases of this disease. Through October of this year, 19 cases have been list ed. Last year there were 26 re ported cases and in 1954 there were 46. Hunters were warned by Dr. Shanholtz to .take every precaution to avoid contracting tularemia which, though rarely fatal, is troublesome and often painful. Al though many wild animals may be infected with tularemia, the .disease occurs most ffequently among wild rabbits, he said. Other animals which can be a source of infection are the tree squirrel, woodchuck, quail, skunk, opossum, deer, fox, and even domesticated animals such as ithe oat or dog. Man becomes infected through the handling of infected animals, such as in skinning or dressing, or by the bate of infected flies or ticks, acocrdiing to the Commission er. He pointed out that in June and July of this year, there were 10 re ported cases of tularemia, most of them attributed to ticks. Tularemia can also be transmitted by eating insufficiently cooked rabbit meat. He also cautioned that freezing the meat does not kill the tularemia bacteria. The onset of the disease is sud den, with chilly, headache, vomit ing, aching, weakness, and always fever. The patient usually is pros trated and confined to bed. An ul cer may appear at the sit4 of infec tion with swelling of the lymph glands in nearby parts of the body. In recent years the antibiotics have been used in the treatment of tu laremia, reducing the duration of the illness from months to weeks. Although convalescence is usually slow, recovery is followed by per manent immunity. Prevention of the disease is mainly a matter of personal pre caution by the hunter or anyone handling wild animals, the Com missioner stated. Sportsmen should avoid shooting slow-moving rab bits and should never pick up mb bits that are fiounid dead or can be killed with a club. These rabbits probably have tularemia. Dr. Shanholtz emphasized, that any person who may be handling raw wild rabbits, such as the hunt er, trapper, housewife, or cook, should wear rubber golves to give protection against contracting tu laremia. Make sure these gloves are leak-proof. Avoid cuts by knives or sharp ends of animal bones while dressing or cooking wild rabbit. Do not touch or rub your eye with your hand. He also pointed out that any small white or grayidh spots no tic ed on the liver of a rabbit are pro bably turaremic abscesses or ulcere. Such a carcass should be be burned and Ithe hands wadhed thoroughly with soap and water. Antiseptic or disinfectant should be used on all open cuts.

document.text: With nearly every eligile voter casting a ballot Tuesday, citizens of the Town of Appomattox named ane automobile dealer, Charles T. Mioses, Jr., as Mayor and another automobile dealer, John S. Ginels as top winner for the six-member Town Council. The Times-Virginian unofficial talley sheet showed Moses ahead, by a dose margin of 220 votes for Mayor to 216 for incumbent Richard D. Robinson. This was the closest race for Mayor here in many years. The ally sheet showed the fol lowing results for Council, with, the top six elected John S. G rin d s ....................... 280 C, Lewis McDeanmon ........... 266 John C, Caldwell . . . . . . . . 261 Grover E. Smith 230 T. Hunter Dickerson . . . . 2215 Clarence C. Poe ................... 269 Mrs. Calvin Roibineon . . . . 206 Ivey Holland ....................... 169 Grover P. Beasley Jr .............. 139 B. H. Guill ........................... 120 J, T. Almond ....................... 11.0 S. J. Evans .......................  . 109 J. T. Irby ................................ 95 The new town officials will take office in September, and serve for a term of two years. The Mayor-elect, Charles Thomas Closes, Jr., is the son of State Sen ator and Mrs. Ohas. T. Moses, of Appomattox. He was born in Appo mattox in August of 1922. He grad uated from Appomattox High School in 1946 and entered Virginia Mili tary Institute in that fall, where he studied until May 1943, when he entered the United States Army as a private. A red letter day in bis life was May 22, 1943, the day on which he received hie War Diploma from Vir ginia Military Institute enlisted .in the U. S. Army and was married to Mies Ruby Martin, the daughter of Mrs. E, B. Martin and the late Mr. Martin, of Oakville. While in the Army, he attained the rank of First Lieutenant in the Combat Engineers. After serving approximately 3 yearn in the mili tary service, inchidingbatii the European and Pacific Theaters, he returned to Appomattox, where he began his business career with the Moses Motor Company, he Chevro let and Oldsmobile Dealership own ed and operated by his father and grandfather, C. T. and T. W. Moses. Charles Thomas and Ruby are the proud parents of three daughters, Joan, Janet and Linda Jo, and an infant son, Charles Thomas, HI, All of the Moses family are mem bers of Memorial Methodist Church, where Charles IteomaD it  member of he Official Board  Charge Lay Leader and a Sunday School teach er. Since his return to Appomattox in 1646, he has been very much in terested -in the .civic affairs of the community. He  helped organize the National Guard Unit at Appomattox and served as its Commanding Of ficer for three years. He has been quite active in the American Le gion, having served aa Commander of the Post 164 for two years, has served as Fourth District Oratorical Chairman for the Legion Depart ment of Virginia, and is a member of the 46  8 Voiture 1133. He is a member and Past Presi dent of the Appomattox Parent- Teacher Association, and is a mem ber of the Appomattox Lions Club. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the Farmers National Bank, and previously served for 3 terms as a member of the Town Council.

document.text: Winchester, Va.The family of Stanley Hunter Hicks, farmer, living near here, was almost entirely wiped out when his wife, Mrs. MaTy Hicks, probably demented from after effects of Influenza, shot and killed three of her four children and then herself. The dead children are Walter, aged 6 Margaret, aged 5, and Stew art, aged 3. The heads of all were blown almost entirely off. The po sition of Walters body Indicated he had tried to shield himself by throw ing up his arm. Hicks, worn out by nursing his wife and children, all of whom have been Indisposed, had been given a sedative by the family physician, and was asleep upstairs. He said he heard only the last shot. His eldest daughter, Mary, aged nine, who was in a bed near her fathers, said she was awake and saw her mother come up stairs, get a single-barrel shotgun and go down. She was unable to awaken her father, before the shooting began, and was herself afraid to go down. - She could hear the children screaming. Mean while the crazed mother had shot and reloaded the gun four times. She fired five shots, one missing. Finally Hicks was aroused and rushed down stairs just to see Mrs. Hicks fire the gun, killing herself. The walls, celling and furniture of tho room resembled a shamble. Taking Mary in his arms, the father, half dressed, ran a mile to the home of his father, Edward M. Hicks, and physicians and officers were called. The authorities were satisfied the woman committed the act while de ranged. She had complained for sev eral days of severe pains In her head and spine.,

document.text: William Paris left for Bluefield Saturday, where he has accepted a lucrative position. Our town will miss his jovial society. Entirely unselfish, his disposition will make him friends wherever be casts bis lot. On Thursday morning the sad death messenger entered the home of Mr. and Mrs. S, L Ferguson and claimed little Harry as its victim. He was only five months of age, but bad endeared itself to the members of the household in such a way that its leaving caused much sorrow. That dreadfully malignant childs disease, cholera infantum, took hold of little Harry and his recovery was soon despaired of. His remains were laid to rest in the cemetery here Friday morning, where a large crowd of friends and relatives as sembled. Revs. Dunkley and Smith conducted the services. Misses Emma Smith, Vera Burke, Alice Burke and Molloy Hunter acted as pall bearers.

document.text: William F. Randolph, Jr., May Die Of Injuries. Berryville Special.William F. Randolph, Jr., formerly of Clarke, now with the Bank of Richmond, at Richmond, was thrown in a hurdle race at the Clarke County horse and colt show and seriously If not fatal ly hurt. In endeavoring to take the third hurdle, just in front of the grand stand, Randolphs mount. True Boy, blundered and fell, throwing young Randolph completely over him. Randolph struck full upon his temple and was rendered uncon scious. He Is In a hosjfital and his condition Is regarded as precarious. In the light-weight hunter class R. M. Peach, of Upperville, riding Aristocrat, was thrown at a hurdle, his mount falling also. He escaped with a few bruises. In the qualified hunters class Edward B. Jacobs, rid ing No Name, fell with hts mount at the first hurdle. His horse fell upon and rolled over him, but Jacobs escaped unhurt and rode the class out.

Alsop will also erect an office on part of the Walden lot, and then our town will be more attractive than ever. Effort is being made to put a new fence around the new passenger yard. W. H. Walden has just com pleted a splendid new paling fence around his residence property. The ladies are making an effort to pnt reflectors in onr church. They believe in plenty of light. Last Thursday Master Bernard Carter had the misfortune to break the small bone in one of his wrists. In running he stumbled and fell, catching his weight upon one hand. wih the above result. On Sunday, the lOib, Mr. E S. Taylor suffered a sudden and se vere attack of illueis. He is now up again, but shows the effect oi his Buffering. Our telephone line is about com pletcd and several of the instru ments have been put np. We art . beginning to feel that we are the people. Capt. W. E. OConnor, accompa nied by his wife, daughter and Master Alfred Tweedy, attended the launching of the battleship Vir ginia at Newport News. Our public schools are closed. Mr. Hunter Brightwell left Sunday for Eastern Shore. On Wednesday, the 13tb, there was a qniet wedding at the parson age. The contracting parties were Mr. Cowan Patterson and Miss Lelia M. Dunam, both of Appo mattox county. Only the pastorr family and a brother of the bride witnessed the ceremony. Oharles A. Oliver, sixteen years of age, after a long and painfnl ill ness, died at his home near I pact on the 13th instant. He was  buried in Prospect Cemetery, Rev. P. M. Bel, his pastor, conducting  the services. He was of a quiet, gentle disposition and seemed to I shrink from the bustle and noise of the crowd, but in his long sick ness he was patient and oalm. The bereaved family have the sympathy of the whole community.

document.text: Who la It?  And W hy It Is D one. - , We have two barber shops at Ap pomattox Depot, Va. One is con ducted by Samuel, J. Hunter, np stairs in the building of Messrs. W, A. Moses A Co. This shop is very well patronized, and . Sam is qnite polite and handy jgivesagood, clean shave and a nice haircutthe above is barber shop No. 1. Now we will see about barber shop No. 2. This is operated by some unknown party. We have two bar rooms in the town, and it is some times the case that some of the pa trons of the barrooms get on too much  skiddy-war-boo, as the In dians call it, and they cannot navi gate they of coarse go for ref age to barber shop No. 2. The w barber  seems glad to see them, and free of charge, the intoxicated man gets a half shave, leaving.half of the lovely mustache as well as half of the beard there. The applicant is taken to the painters shop, who gives his face a coat of paintit seems to de pend on the color of the applicant as to what colors are used in paint ing his face. Now remember, this barber shop No. 2 and the painters shop are only kept open for the bene fit of those who are too drank to walk home before taking their rest. The  barber  in shop No. 2 seems to be kind hearted and generous, because he charges nothing, as has been stated before, to do half of the work, while barber No. 1 gets as much for the last half as he would have gotten for the whole job. Look ont old men, young men and boys. You may not escape because you lave no beard, as you all have a suit of hair, and that is in danger. Be careful and do not drink too modi, and yon will escape. But If you go to sleep by the use of too much kiddy-war-boo. You may Bud yourselfor selvesin barber shop No. 3. Now, boys, take warning, from what you have seen. Do not call the barber in shop No. 2 mean But leave off the fearful drink, Or else yon and your property are bound to sink. As a medicine it llB very fine thing to use, But never, no never, was it mado to abuse. B uster .

document.text: white straw basket of petals. Ringbearer was Master Zane Torrence of Appomattox and junior usher was M aster Dewitt Goin of Prospect. Mr. David Thomas Calkins of Detroit, Michigan, brother of the groom, was best man. Ushers were Harold Wyatt of Appomattox, and Harold How ard of Lynchburg. For her daughters wedding,  Mrs. Brown selected a floor length gown fashioned of quiana in a persimmon tone. The bodice was finished with a high dropped neckline and long straight sleeves. Mrs. Calkins, mother of the groom, wore a floor length shirtwaist Molly Paraio design of silk jersey in a golden beige color with white leaves scattered on the background. They both wore a corsage of stephanotis and spider mums with color accents of their gowns. Mrs. Herbert Garrett and Mrs. Robert Garrett were MfStresses dQBremqmes,. _ egisted In the brides book by Mrs. John Burns of Gettsyburg, Pennsyl vania. Following the ceremony, the bride8 parents entertained with a reception in the church. The reception was hosted by Mrs. Barbara Dickerson of Prospect, cousin of the bride, with Mrs. Frank Goin, Mrs. Hunter Goin and Mrs. George Kress assisting. Cutting the cake were Mrs, Dennis Torrence and Mrs. Richard Jones. Mrs. David Smith and Mrs. Ed Schampel served at the punch bowl. The flower arrangements for the church and the home of the bride were done by Mrs. Schampel. The bride is a graduate of Appomattox County High School and is presently attending Longwood College. The bridegroom is currently employed with Appomattox Court House National Histori cal park and is also attending Longwood College. After a southern wedding trip, the couple will make their home in Appomattox. Present at the wedding were the brides grandmother and her husband, Mr. and Mrs. Walker Shupe. Also present, were the aunts of the bride, Mr. and Mrs. James Jennings of

document.text: While hitching a young mule John Henry Cobb, of Buckingham County, was kicked. His skull was fractured and he was injured internally. Mr. Cobb is a leading planter of his county and is a brother-in-law of Mayor H. A. Maurice, of Manchester. J. A. Stringer, a well-known citizen of Manchester, has disappeared, and his friends fear foul play. He has not been seen since he left home Saturday morn ing. Leonard C. Carson probably was fatal ly injured by a fall from the new Capi tol building, Richmond. The Corporation Commission has hartered the Colbourn Bros. Oyster Company, of Whealton, with a capital of 50,000. A S. Colbourn is president, G. 3. Howeth vice-president and W. W. Marshall treasurer. Morris Isenton and Henry Bord, pawnbrokers, of Portsmouth, were ar- -ested by United States Marshal West I sn the charge of receiving revolvers which were stolen from the United States Government. The revolvers are valued at 15 each, and it is alleged hat Henry Crofutt, a sergeant of ma rines, sold one and J. Miller, a marine, sold the other. These are the specific harges which will be presented to the grand jury now, but recently the officers yf the navy seized many wagonloads of property in the stores of the pawnbrok- rs said to be worth 10,000. The com mandant of the station and the officers of the court have determined to sup press stealing from the ships and the. navy yard.  Two tickets have been announced for he approaching Lexington municipal flection the incumbent, Mayor Samuel B. Walker, Jr., and Capt. W. F. Pier son, former Mayor of the town. Mayori Walkers Council is composed of Messrs Paul M. Penick, W. P. Irwin, C. R., Deaver, G. W. Offlighter, A. G. Hutton ind Dr. Hunter Pendleton. A ll except he last two are members of the present Council. Capt. Piersons associates are Dr. James Lewis Howe, Dr. Reid White, Messrs. M. B. Corse, Lawrence Em- bree, L. B. Miller and T. H. Boiey. The election will take place June 13. Virginia Institute, Bristol, has just dosed a successful year. The annual lit erary address was delivered by Dr. W. 9 . Pickard, of Lynchburg. The young ladies receiving diplomas were Misses Cates, Moffett, Floy Harris, Selma Bur- ion, Emma Gholston, Alice Huskms, Cynthia Orr, Pauline Cody and Marian Johnson. Gardiner  Clark and Mahan  Tyree, wo wholesale produce firms, of Danville, were burned out. The two concerns oc- supy a three-story brick structure, owned by Mr. J. R. Jopling. The insurance on building and goods will nearly cover the loss. , . The new catalogue of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute shows the total number of students who have matricu lated for the session of 1904-1905 to be 728. Among these there are men from nearly every State in the Union, Argen tina, Canada, Cuba, Ecuador, Newfound land, Santo Domingo and Spain. Out of the senior class of 103 it is expected that about 75 or 80 will receive diplomas on commencement day. The Jewish congregation of Temple Emmanuel, of Roanoke, has _ purchased the church property of the United Breth ren and will in the future occupy it as a place of worship. Engineer A. A. Linkous, of the Nor folk and Western Railroad, had his left hand crushed off under his engine one night last week at Glade Spring. He was under the engine adjusting a part of the machinery when the engineer on an other locomotive attached to the same train pulled the throttle, starting the train. Mr. Linkous, whose home is at Vickers, barely escaped with his life. The following night some miscreant shot into the westbound passenger train of the Norfolk and Western soon after the train left Marion. The ball passed through the day coach within a few inches of the head of the conductor, Captain Walters. News has been received in Bristol that Manager Kenyon, of the Helena Lumber Company, met a tragic fate in the mountains near Damascus. A log car ran away down the mountain and collided with a car on which Mr. Ken-  yon was seated. He was thrown under  the wheels and instantly killed, his body  being mangled. Mr. Kenyon was about 50 years old. His home was at Caze- novia, N. Y.  It is reported in Bristol, although the ! report lacks confirmation, that George I L. Carter has bought the coal and min- j eral interests of the Interstate Coal and ! Iron Company, in Southwest Virginia.  The price reported to have been paid i for the companys possessions is 275,- j 000. The civil engineer of the Inter state Company Has left Southwest Vir-  ginia and is looking after the companys j interests in lower East Tennessee. Elbert Boyd, a young man who was ! to have been tried at Blountsville, Tenn., for the murder of Thomas Galloway, i has been adjudged insane by a Bristol j ! jury that heard evidence as to his men- i ial condition. He will be sent to an! 1 aSyium. The jurys verdict provided that should Boyd eventually recover his mindj he is to be brought back and tried for murder. .......  _ For the murder of William S. Bur- on a highly respected citizen of Southjj Bristol, who was shot to death one nighty last fall, Grover and Clinton Wilson orothers, both young men, were sentenced 0 15 years each in the penitentiary. The mitigating circumstance that saved them from the death penalty was that some of heir neighbors had threatened them with iolence if they did not leave the com munity. Thomas J. Glass, aged 40, a lineman or the Bristol Gas and Electric Com pany, was killed almost instantly. He 1 nad climbed up to the top of a 30-foot Dole to adjust a wire, when the pole ! broke in two at the bottom and fell, j etching the lineman and crushing in Dis breast. Glass is survived by a widow ! and three little daughters. His aged mother resides in Richmond, and is now i critically ill. . . The board of trustees of the Uni- ! rersity College of Medicine, Richmond, I las elected Dr. John F. Winn to the  ffiair of clinical obstetrics.

document.text: which were never answered and! travelling five and seven miles urg ing the Appomattox ladies to join and help them. They were in formed with an indifferent smile, that they had other important du ties and home affairs claiming their time, and their quarters could be better spent elsewhere than on the dead. In one seuse this is true. We have home duties and try not to neglect them, aud the monev ould be possibly more wisely spent While we do this to honor our dead, we try also to impress npo. the minds of the children of the county, hat the Confederate cause was just .ml right and thatthir fathers were not rebellious traitors and to give them a desire to acquire knowledge of the events of their country, and to teach, them to be patriotic aud proud of their South-land and an cestors. The little knowledge, be ginning here may grow in the minds and hearts of each, and be of great benefit to all. The president of the U. D. C. thought last year of giviug up the charter of the Appo mattox Chapter U. D. C. on account of the ladies lack of interest in this county. She wrote the National l D. C. president, and the Virginia president U. D. C. to that effect, stating she would join a chapter in Lynchburg. Letters from the Va. division, S. C. division and Md. di vision came pouring in not to let Appomattox surrender the second time also sending a list of names of prominent ladies who would join among them, Miss Ruth Early, Mrs. James Garnett, Miss M. Amelia Smith, the piesideut of Va. division U. D. C. and the daughter of ex-Gov Wm. Smith of Va., known as Ex tra Billy. The letter expressed surprise at the Appomattox ladies not caring to join one of the largest organizations m the whole south and living in one of the most his torical counties in the world. It is quite a reflection upon the county. We revised the roll and now have ouly eighteen members lu t they say they intend to keep up the or ganization and to be proud they are U. O C. of Appomattox and we shall be more than pleased if Coal ing will forward us the names ot the ladies desiring to join the IT, D. C. or the Memorial Association or any one reading this would like to become a member of either society please forward their name to Mrs. T. A. Smith, president of the Mem orial Association or Mrs. C. W. Hunter, president of U. D. C. West Appomattox. One prominent aim of the U. D. C. is to gather histori cal facts to help the historians of the U. D. 0. historical committee in collecting war experiences, inci dents and reminiscences of the old soldiers, their wives, daughters or any one who can remember during the Civil war. The U. D. C. es pecially requests, Mrs. T. W. Johns to write up hers and Capt. Johns also Mrs. George Miles, Mrs. A. H. Bocock, Major Flood, Mr. Chap Chilton, Drs. Wm. White and Wm. H. Ahbitt, Mrs. Mary Ann Robert son, Mr. Kirk Hannah and any one who will help us, also send us news paper clippings or Magazines or Journals or anything bearing on the war between the states. This is to help in having a correct history of the south. Please dont think yours will not be of service or interest for it may show up the spirit of the times more than you think. A D a u g h t e r .

document.text: When youre new in town you inevitably make several trips to the Post Office.Rarely though, can you pick up your mail and buy a loaf of bread at the same place. Rarely can you buy a coke and sit down and know that the Post Master will make time to chat and generally make you feel hes glad that you stopped by. Norman Hunter Jones is just such a Post Master. Post Offi services approximately 1500 people, with many families picking up their mail from Mr. Jones each day. This Post Office was originally establish ed during the 1800s but the present building was built in 1954, the year Mr. Jones became Post Blaster. Yes, thats right, hes been serving the community for 22 years. A quiet man, with an in ate sense of dignity, hell tell you hes lived a simple life. If youre persistent, you might learn that he served in the Air Force during World War IL He was in the China-India-Burma

document.text: What Shall The Preacher Preach. A beautiful picture was brought out in this message. The anniversary commit tee consisted of Mrs. Rosa Hurtt. Chair lady, Mrs. Sadie Scott, co-chairlady. Others Rev. Alvin Jones, Deacon and Mrs. S. M. Hunter stand by. The welcome was done by Deacon S. W. Hunter in a very effective way. Deacon James E. Tweedy gave the achievements of the pastor. Rev. Alvin Jones introduced the speaker. The offering was taken by Deacons S. R. . Marshall, W. R. Jones and W. M. Scott. Presentation from the church. Deacon S. W. Marshall, presentations from all other auxiliaries, Mrs. Cathrine Tweedy. Re.v. McLaughlin was present and gave remarks of gratitude. .A Mr. Goey from Memorial Baptist Church Halifax, made a presentation from their church of which Rev. McLaughlin is their newly elected pastor. This was a great event and was enjoyed by all. A repass was served in the dining area of the Church. On the third Sunday -in October Mrs. Louise Canada and Mrs. Anna Canada and Mrs. Iny Pattrick attended a portion of the installation service of the newly elected pastor of the Green Spring Church. Pastor is the Rev. Carlton Jackson. From there they journeyed to the Christian Tabernacle Chur ch to join the other members of thevSt. Luke Choir who attended the anniversary of the choir there. This was a great musical event and the spirit was high and was a very successful event. The First St. Luke Gospel Chorus will be sponsoring a bake sale at the St. Luke Church Dec. 13 beginning at 1200 noon. Please come and purchase something good to eat for the benefit of the chorus.
